intro: Verbesina oppositiflora, commonly known as the showy beggar-ticks, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk flowers. The plant produces yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late summer to early fall, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are opposite, heart-shaped, and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are hairy and often reddish in color. Verbesina oppositiflora is typically found in moist, open habitats like woodland edges and prairies.
